Elliott et al -
	That would be Yokoyama Sukeyoshi, who worked in Bizen and =
Fukuyama  
Bingo on the cusp of the Modern era. His dated works are from Ke=
io  
(1865) and Meiji(1868). Sounds like a very cool tsuba, can't wait to  =

see the pictures. I have to admit, like Richard, I enjoy those late  
Edo =
swordsmiths tsuba. I just bought a papered 11th generation  
Yasutsugu tsub=
a at last weekends Taikai.
	Addressing Richards question, the Yasutsugu tsu=
ba I have seen are  
rather plain, while Masahide seems to have put a lot o=
f work into his  
tsuba. Pure speculation but I would think he would have p=
resented the  
tsuba as a separate independant work. Who would want all tha=
t work  
overshadowed by  a blade or vice versa. I base it solely on my ill=
- 
informed ideas of what a craftsman like Masahide was all about.
FWIW
-t
=
